entry.title: Re: Need to know how can Return Revenue GL can be assigne...
entry.content:
Hello @abulhasnat

1.  For exclusion, so the return condition is used and the standard one is ignored, I suggest you use Condition Exclusion in the same pricing procedure. Therefore, you should:

  • Try and create two conditions ZSTD for standard, ZRET for returns and assign different Account Keys.
  • Create an Exclusion group containing those conditions in your CBC pricing configuration.
  • Then assign the conditions to your pricing procedure and set the rule so only one gets involved.

So, that will ensure your pricing keeps only one and thereby standard condition is ignored for returns. See KBA 3641244, Condition Exclusion, and Condition Exclusion for Pricing Procedure for more guidance.

2.  You do not need to change Copy Control 102763 for custom field.

Yes, you often cannot edit 102763 in CBC. You should consider using Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents instead of copy control routines. You can:

  • First is to create the custom field in Custom Fields and Logic and enable it for Billing Document.
  • Then implement Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents to copy the value you need into the billing document custom field.
  • You should maintain Assign Data Transfer Route to Copying Control Setting for the delivered LR2 --> G2 copying relationship in CBC. This does not mean you are creating a new copy control entry, rather you are assigning the routine to the existing one.

After that, you can use that custom field in Revenue Account Determination to derive your return revenue GL.

See KBA 3269803, Assign the Data Transfer Routine to Copying Control Settings and Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents for more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
Hi @Chris1973,

1.  For exclusion, so the return condition is used and the standard one is ignored, I suggest you use Condition Exclusion in the same pricing procedure. Therefore, you should:

  • Try and create two conditions PPR0 for standard, ZINV for returns, and assign different account keys. - I completely understand and created and assigned.
  • Create an Exclusion group containing those conditions in your CBC pricing configuration. - I have created Exculsion group containing those conditions and configured it. 
     

     

  • Then assign the conditions to your pricing procedure and set the rule so only one gets involved

Hasnat

entry.title: Re: Not able to edit supplier invoice
entry.content:
Hello @jerrysam 

Thank you for your question

What you described may happen for some reasons.

  • Can you confirm the User have the authorisation to edit and post for parked invoices? If no, that might explain why UI does not display the edit actions.
  • Also, check if your workflow or backend process is stuck. As this might also explain why your invoice remains Parked as Completed instead of posting.

See the following reference for more details: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2836297

Please note that, if your “Smart Fix” Process posts invoices through a central invoice intake solution, some statuses cannot be edited in the central app and you must open them in the connected S4 system or vice versa.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Building a Graph Native AI Chatbot on SAP BTP
entry.content:
The true intelligence and accuracy of an enterprise AI chatbot depends on one thing, Data Access. While most chatbots rely on standard API calls to fetch information, it hits a wall when dealing with complex, interconnected business logic.

The Problem: Chatbot's rely on API calls to extract data from source system. APIs are designed for transactions and not data exploration. For example, if a user asks, 'Show me the total revenue impact of C4C service tickets related to S/4HANA orders delayed by supplier issues,' .

A traditional chatbot is stuck. It would need to orchestrate a number of cross-system OData calls, join the data in memory, and calculate the results often resulting in high latency or timeouts.

The Solution: SAP HANA Graph

The better approach is by combining the LLM with the Graph Schema in SAP HANA, we can bypass these limitations entirely. In this blog, I will show you how to build a Graph-Native Agentic AI that understands your data relationships intuitively.

Instead of viewing data as API endpoints, we model it as a Property Graph. Here, the business entities (like Customers, Sales Orders, Service Tickets, Products) are represented as Vertex(Nodes) and their relations are the Edges.

Deep-Node Traversals:

The graph allows the chatbot to traverse relationships instantly. In a single query it can hop from a Customer node -->Sales Order node -->Line Item node --> Product node, collect the necessary data and send it to the LLM which is then sent to the user.

The graph engine natively supports aggregations(SUM,COUNT) directly in the database layer during node traversal

We can physically link a C4C Service Ticket node to a S/4HANA Sales Order node. The graph schema identifies only the data relation and not the system of origin.

Representation of interconnected Business Objects that form a graph.

 

Let's See it in Action - Demo Video

Conceptualizing a graph traversal can be difficult, so let’s look at how the chatbot handles a query involving Sales Cloud scenario:

Why I chose Property Graph?

  • vs. Knowledge Graphs: While Knowledge Graphs focus on semantics and inference (great for unstructured data), Property Graphs focus on structure and attributes, which fits enterprise data better.
  • Rich Context: Relationship between Business Objects carry properties. For example, a relationship between a Customer and a Product isn't just a relationship link, it contains transaction details like: CUSTOMER --> BOUGHT {ProductID: 10005824, Date: 20/01/2026, Quantity: 5, Price: $100} --> PRODUCT
  • Mathematical Aggregations: Property Graph engines are optimized to perform aggregations (Sum Revenue, Count Tickets, Avg) on the fly during data traversal. 
  • Accuracy: We rely on strict graph schema definitions to ensure the LLM generates accurate, hallucination free queries.

Architecture:

To enable this real-time graph agent, I implemented a robust data fabric on SAP BTP.

Real-time data fabric

We utilize SAP Datasphere to act as the pipeline for data source & replication. By replicating the raw tables into SAP HANA via Datasphere, we ensure the data is real-time. Once the data is replicated to HANA, the Graph Workspace is created on top of these tables, defining the vertexes (nodes) and edges (relationships) virtually.

Handling Federated Data Scenarios

In cases where data cannot be not replicated to SAP HANA(volume constraints), the architecture adapts seamlessly. The Graph LLM retains its logic and identifies the necessary nodes(vertices) and query parameters based on the user prompt. Instead of generating a openCypher query these parameters are mapped to optimized OData calls to the source system. This ensures a streamlined, real-time federation strategy that shows the precision of a graph traversal.

Schema Injection

The graph schema(the definition of Nodes and Edges) is injected to LLM at run time. Based on the user query the LLM will first identify the nodes, data traversal path and the logic.

For the query: “Who are my top 5 customers by sales volume who also have open critical tickets?”

The LLM determines the execution plan:

  • Nodes Identified: BusinessPartner (Customer), SalesOrder, ServiceRequest
  • Traversal Paths:
    • BusinessPartner --> SalesOrder (To calculate volume)
    • BusinessPartner <-- ServiceRequest (To find the open tickets)
  • Filters Applied:
    • ServiceRequest.LifeCycleStatus = 'Open'
    • ServiceRequest.Priority = 'Critical'
  • Aggregation: Sum of SalesOrder.NetAmount grouped by Customer.
  • Ranking: Order by Sum Descending, Limit 5.

openCypher Query Generation

Once the LLM identifies the graph query plan, the actual openCypher query is generated programmatically using python. I did not use LLM here as the openCypher wrapped in HANA is tricky and requires precise syntax.

The openCypher query is executed directly against the SAP HANA Graph engine and the result is passed to the LLM to generate a natural language summary.

Transactional Updates (Write Scenarios)

For maintaining transaction data, the Agentic AI brings in a mandatory human-in-the-loop confirmation step before any data is written via a POST request. You can see the technical implementation steps for this human intervention logic in my earlier blog post.

User Interface & Deployment

The core Chatbot agent is deployed on SAP BTP. For the front end, I utilized SAP Build Apps to create a clean, low-code user interface. The app connects to the BTP agent and provides a seamless chat experience for the business user.

Conclusion

By moving from API loops to Graph Traversals, we unlock the true potential of Enterprise AI. We get the speed of database-level aggregation with the flexibility of natural language processing.

Reference:

Refer this blog to understand about the implementation of Agentic AI Chatbot using LangGraph - The power of AI Agents: My Journey with LangGraph

entry.title: Re: Balance Sheet/Income Statement - Multidimensional
entry.content:
Hello @jantoniomoyano3 

Thank you for your question

On your quest to modify FS Leaf External ID, the simple answer is the public cloud does not permit that. The reason is the field is a technical external ID used by the report logic which is not designed for user to maintain in the app or through configuration. Extensibility or customisation is also not supported for this report family.

Instead of that, you can however, maintain a business-friendly description in your Financial Statements Version and display those in your report instead of the external ID.

Below is a short description of what to consider:

In your Tenant, open Manage Global Hierarchies, open your FSV hierarchy, maintain the node of leaf texts, activate it, in your Balance Sheet statement, use the display with descriptions and not the external ID.

If your goal is only to not show YCOA, remove that column from the layout and save your view. You can do this in your report by opening settings, then go to Column, then unselect FS Leaf External ID and keep the descriptive fields. Finally save it as a variant or you may also bookmark it.

See KBA 3641756, Configuring a New Financial Statement Version and Balance Sheet / Income Statement - Multidimensional for more details.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: How to capitalize transfer/transportation cost on an intra-company STO
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m testing Stock Transport Orders (STO) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition for a plant-to-plant transfer inside the same company code (intra-company). The operational flow works fine:

  • STO created (UB/stock transport type)

  • Outbound delivery created

  • Picking + PGI in supplying plant

  • GR in receiving plant

  • Stock arrives correctly and quantity is updated

My issue

I need to add a transportation / transfer cost (freight) to this transfer so it becomes part of the inventory valuation of the stock received in the receiving plant (i.e., increase the receiving plant inventory value by the freight amount).

But in the standard intra-company STO flow, the inventory value at GR remains the same as the issuing plant’s valuation, and the transportation cost is not added.

What I tried

  1. Adding costs inside the STO (looking for “Conditions” / pricing)

    • It is not available in STO creation, Tab does not show 

  2. Posting freight through supplier invoice functions (planned/unplanned delivery costs)

    • I tried to post it as unplanned delivery costs, but I got messages like:

      • “No items found to which unplanned delivery costs can be distributed”

      • “No goods items found / No suitable item found”

    •        It seems the STO isn’t invoice-relevant like a normal vendor PO.

  3. In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, is there an SAP-standard way to capitalize transfer freight on an intra-company STO (same company code) so it increases inventory value at the receiving plant?

entry.title: Streamlining Cost Sharing Process in SAP Grants Management
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

For those intereted in the public sector accounting, if they have ready my previous blog on SAP Grants Management An Introduction to SAP Grants Management ,  they must have got a good idea of how SAP Grants Management works to meet the sponsor reporting requirments . The blog explained in details the end to end process of obataining, posting and reporting Grants from Grantee perspective. In this article, we will be covering cost sharing part of SAP Grants Management.

In some grants, there is a clause as per MoU signed that Grantee will also be contributing to some cost of the project beside Sponsor who is already funding the project. This is where the concept of Cost sharing comes into picture and it plays a pivotal role in satisfying the sponsor'e resporting requirment without compromising the internal processes of Finance. We will now deep dive into some of key concepts of Cost Sharing in SAP Grants Management.

GM Fund Type:

In the grant master data, a fund of type external is always needed and there can only be one fund external fund in the grant, however we can always add fund of type internal within the grant for cost sharing scenarios. Funding received from the grantor are recorded on the External fund level and contribution from the grantee are recorded on the internal fund.

Grant Master Cost Sharing Fund

If you want to maintain cost sharing settings on the grant master you need to flag at least one internal fund for cost sharing.

The fund is available in budgeting, as well as on all commitment- and expense-generating transactions such as purchasing documents, travel commitment, direct FI expense postings etc. This allows the companies to separate the sponsor and grantee contributions for all the relevant business processes, and also in reporting.

The classifiction of fund as internal and external is mandatory for the cost sharing process which can be done in IMG>>Public Sector Management>>Grants Management>>Grantee Management>>Master Data>>Fund>>Maintain GM Fund Type for FM Fund Type

FM Fund Type

Capturing Cost Sharing in Grant:

Within a Grant, cost sharing can be done in two unique ways.

Additive Calculation of Cost Sharing budgets
The sponsor/grantor does not want to see the complete grant relevant project budget but he just defines his funding i-e the amount he can fund for the project.  The grantee’s contribution is then calculated as a percentage of the externally funded amounts (sponsor’s contribution) in order to cover the project. The grantee’s contribution is added to the sponsor’s funding.

Subtractive Calculation of Cost Sharing budgets (available as of release 603)
The sponsor wants to see the complete grant relevant project budget and defines their funding as a share of this total budget. Therefore the grantee’s contribution is then calculated as a percentage of the total amount (externally and internally funded). From the total the cost sharing is subtracted in order to have the sponsor’s contribution.

Budgeting Cost Sharing:

Budgeting of Cost Sharing is done in two steps
1.- Enter budget

2.- Allocate

These steps are based on the GM document type, where we can see what kind of funding it is: Sponsors funding, or Cost Sharing funding.

In GM_CREATE_BUDGET , I have entered net amount of 10M USD for the Grant as shown.

Budget Entry View-Sponsor

We can see the cost sharing information in the cost sharing tab as shown below.

Cost Sharing View-Grantee Contribution

At this point , we will post 10 Million USD sponsor budget for 3 years.

New we will choose document type configured exclusively for Cost Sharing as shown and post the Grantee share of Grant which is 260,000 USD.

Cost Sharing Budget-2.6 Million USD

Cost Sharing-Completed Allocation

GMAVCOVRW - Overview of GM AVC Values report shows both Sponsor and Grantee view of the Grant as shown below making the total Grant value based on the additive cost sharing rule to 12.6 Million USD.

GMAVCOVRW - Overview of GM AVC Values

Recording Actuals/Commitments:

Commitments and actuals on the grant with shared costs can be setup easily using the appropriate derivation rules for the postings. FMDERIVE and GMDERIVE have to be setup properly to accomodate the grants requirments. Consumption on above GM Account assignment can be done via FI posting or P2P process.

P2P-Commitment Generation

GM-GTE Commitment Document Overview

There is Useful KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003680745 to automate Cost sharing process using Rule Based Account Assignment , I will cover this process in some future blog.

Thank you for your time to read this blog 😊.

entry.title: Re: How to export a photo column (data type image) in a t...
entry.content:
See xp_write_file  or  WRITE_CLIENT_FILE system procedures.  The xp_write_file is relative to the server. If you want the files written to a client, use WRITE_CLIENT_FILE.  Here are examples use the demo datbase Products table.

-- save relative to the server
select xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\server\\' || ID || '.jpg', photo) from GROUPO.Products;

-- save relative to the client
set option allow_write_client_file = 'On';
select WRITE_CLIENT_FILE( 'C:\\\temp\\client\\' || ID || '.jpg', photo) from GROUPO.Products;
set option allow_write_client_file = 'Off';

 If you have more that one column that you want process, simply repeat the xp_write_file or WRITE_CLIENT_FILE for each of the columns.  For example, the following saves imageCol1 and ImageCol2  from table SampleTab.

select 
      xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\imageCol1\\' || ID || '.jpg', imageCol1)
    , xp_write_file( 'C:\\temp\\imageCol2\\' || ID || '.jpg', imageCol2)
from SampleTab

entry.title: Adding revenue contract and performance obligation to Fiori AppDisplay Line Items in General Entries
entry.content:
Why Add These Fields?

When using CBRR, SAP automatically enriches journal entries with revenue contract and performance obligation IDs. The related postings, such as revenue recognition, revenue adjustment from invoice correction and balance sheet postings, are posted directly with the revenue contract and performance obligation IDs.  These identifiers are essential for:

  • Tracing postings back to revenue contracts
  • Supporting reconciliation and audit processes
  • Enabling detailed margin and revenue analysis
  • Improving user efficiency in daily operations

While Manage Journal Entries allows filtering by these fields, it does not provide the same line‑item list view that business users rely on. Adding the fields to the line‑item apps closes this gap.

What You Need Before You Start

This enhancement requires:

  • Access to the Custom Fields app (Extensibility role from the template role: SAP_BR_EXTENSIBLITY_SPEC)
  • No technical development or custom fields — SAP delivers the fields already in ACDOCA

Time required: 20–30 minutes.

Step‑by‑Step Guide: Adding the Fields

Step 1 — Open the Custom Fields App

Navigate to: Extensibility → Custom Fields

This app allows you to extend SAP‑delivered UIs with additional fields.

Step 2 — Create a Data Source Extension

Go to the Data Source Extension tab, and Click Create

Select the data source extension FAC_GLV_GL_ACCOUNT_LINE_ITEMS_SRV ( Display Line Items in General Ledger )

Enter a description (SAP will propose an extension ID automatically).  Example: Revenue Contract

Click Create to continue

Step 3 — Add the Required Fields

In the field selection screen,  click the Search icon.

Search for Revenue Accounting Contract.

Select the field and click Apply.

Repeat the process for Performance Obligation / Performance Application

These fields exist in the Universal Journal but are not part of the default field catalog — which is why this extension is necessary.

Step 4 — Publish the Extension

Accept the default labels,  Click Save & Publish.

SAP will now add these fields to the field catalog of the relevant apps.  Publishing may take a few minutes.

Step 5 — Verify the Fields in the Apps

Open Display Line Items in General Ledger (and similarly Margin Analysis)

In the Filter Bar

Click Adapt Filters and confirm that you now see:

  • Revenue Accounting Contract
  • Performance Obligation

In the List View

Open Settings → Adapt Columns and add:

  • Revenue Accounting Contract
  • Performance Obligation

These fields can now be used for filtering, sorting, and reporting.

Recommended Best Practice

In the Fiori App ‘Display Line Items in General Ledger’ and ‘Display Line Items in Margin Analysis’,  you can create and save a custom view that includes these fields and share it with business users. This ensures consistent reporting across the project

Summary

Adding Revenue Contract and Performance Obligation IDs to the line‑item apps is:

  • Simple — no coding required
  • SAP‑standard — uses delivered extensibility
  • Valuable — improves transparency and analysis
  • Fast — completed in under 30 minutes

This enhancement is especially useful for organizations implementing Contract‑Based Revenue Recognition and wanting to streamline operational reporting.

If the legacy API has its own buffering mechanism then let's reuse that as a transactional buffer, right?
If there's no buffering then the API is not transactional and the unmanaged scenario doesn't make sense because there would be nothing to utilize in the CRUD methods. All your API calls can be made in determinations, validations, and ultimately in method save_modified just fine if you choose managed with unmanaged save.

entry.title: cds-toon-ai-protocol-adapter: a pragmatic way to cut AI token costs using SAP CAP
entry.content:
If you’ve been experimenting with AI in enterprise apps, you’ve probably felt the "token tax". It’s the silent cost hidden in every JSON payload you stream to an LLM. The more verbose the structure, the more you pay, both in latency and in cost.

This is exactly where the cds-toon-ai-protocol-adapter lands: a small, composable CAP plugin that brings the TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation) protocol to your services. So you can keep your code, keep your patterns, and still send leaner payloads to AI systems.

In short:

  • It adds TOON as a protocol to CAP (REST and OData variants)
  • It automatically converts JSON ↔ TOON on the wire
  • It can auto-pick the most token-efficient response format
  • It logs token statistics so you can quantify the win

It's is directly inspired by an article I read on medium: "TOON, MCP and Agents: Less Hype, More Real Architecture (and a 25% Saving That Actually Matters)".

Toon procotol adapter in action

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Why Toon in CAP?

Let’s start with the pain:

  • JSON is great for machines and tools, but it’s verbose for LLMs
  • LLM pricing and latency scale with tokens, not bytes
  • Sending full JSON schemas, deeply nested objects, and descriptive keys is comfortable for us, but expensive for models

TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation) flips that mindset:

  • It’s a compact, human-readable, model-friendly representation
  • It removes structural noise while keeping semantic meaning
  • It often reduces token counts by 20–50% compared to JSON

What the adapter gives you in CAP:

  • A protocol-level optimization, no refactors in service logic
  • Opt-in per service via @protocol annotations
  • Automatic conversion on responses (JSON → TOON), optional on requests (TOON → JSON)
  • A safety net: it can auto-decide per response if JSON is actually cheaper and choose that instead

So the real "why" is simple: you can introduce AI cost and latency optimizations where they belong, at the boundary, without touching domain logic, entities, or your CAP service handlers.

Where it fits in your architecture

If your CAP service:

  • Feeds agents with app context
  • Exposes APIs to AI tools or MCP-style execution flows

…then the adapter sits right at the edge of your service. Clients can consume Toon endpoints or keep using JSON/OData, your service handlers continue to speak plain JavaScript objects. Meanwhile, the adapter keeps score and trims the fluff.

How to use it (in less than 5 minutes)

1) Install

npm install @geertjanklaps/cds-toon-ai-protocol-adapter

Make sure you’re on @sap/cds >= 9.

2) Annotate your service with the Toon protocol

REST-style TOON:

@protocol: ['toon']
service MyToonService {
}

Prefer OData compatibility but want TOON on the wire?

@protocol: ['toon-odata']
service MyToonService {
}

3) Implement your service as usual

NoTOON-specific code needed. No new SDK. Your handlers stay clean.

4) Configure behavior in package.json

{
  "cds": {
    "toonAdapter": {
      "requestProcessingEnabled": false,
      "responseProcessingEnabled": true,
      "logTokenStatistics": true,
      "autoDetermineResponseContentType": true
    }
  }
}

What this means:

  • responseProcessingEnabled: true → your JSON responses can be converted to TOON
  • requestProcessingEnabled: false → clients can still send JSON; turn this on if you want to accept TOON requests too
  • autoDetermineResponseContentType: true → the adapter will send TOON or JSON based on which uses fewer tokens for that response
  • logTokenStatistics: true → you’ll see logs like: [toon] - Token count - JSON: 150, TOON: 95, Difference: 55 (36,7%)

5) Call the endpoints

  • REST base: /toon/
    • Example: GET /toon/my-toon-service/getData
  • OData base: /toon-odata/
    • Example: GET /toon-odata/my-toon-odata-service/getData

By default, clients can still send JSON. If you enable TOON requests, they can POST with Content-Type: text/toon.

When to use it

Ideal scenarios:

  • AI/LLM integrations where every token counts
  • Near-real-time experiences where shaving tokens reduces latency
  • Cost-sensitive workloads or multi-tenant setups where savings compound

Observed benefits:

  • Token reduction: typically 20–50% vs JSON
  • Lower bandwidth usage
  • Reduced AI API cost and faster roundtrips

This is not about "changing your data model for AI", it’s about optimizing the transport layer so your CAP services can collaborate with AI systems efficiently.

Practical tips:

  • Don’t refactor your code. Add the protocol, turn on responseProcessingEnabled, and measure
  • Keep autoDetermineResponseContentType enabled in production. Sometimes JSON is cheaper, let the adapter pick the winner
  • Enable logTokenStatistics in development and load tests. Record baseline token counts before/after
  • If you expose an MCP server using @gavdi/cap-mcp, use the toon-odata protocol

A minimal test you can run today

  1. Enable TOON on a read-heavy service
  2. Turn on logTokenStatistics
  3. Hit endpoints with realistic data (lists, expansions, nested structures)
  4. Compare JSON vs TOON token counts in logs
  5. Forward the same responses to your AI layer and measure end-to-end latency and cost

Expect measurable token drops on non-trivial payloads. In multi-tenant scenarios, those savings add up, quietly and meaningfully.

Closing thoughts

We don’t need more hype around "AI-native" architectures. We need small, composable decisions that make our systems cheaper, faster, and more maintainable. The cds-toon-ai-protocol-adapter does exactly that for CAP:

  • No rewrites.
  • Real savings.
  • Better UX for agents and LLMs.

If you’re serious about bringing AI into your SAP landscape, start where it hurts the budget: tokens on the wire. Add TOON at the protocol layer, measure, and move on to the next pragmatic win.

Useful links:

  • NPM: @geertjanklaps/cds-toon-ai-protocol-adapter
  • Issues and support: GitHub repository
  • Toon documentation: @toon-format/toon

If you try this in a multi-tenant setup or with MCP-heavy flows, I’d love to hear your numbers!

entry.title: MCP Server for On Premise data
entry.content:
What is Model Context Protocol ?

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is an open-source standard for connecting AI applications to external systems.

An MCP server can provide access to  data sources, tools and apps within S4HANA which will enhance capabilities of an AI agent.

It allows an interface to  securely access tools, data and services.

For an ECC / S/4HANA system MCP can provide a solution to certain long-standing problems that customers have.

  • No access to ERP data for AI applications and agents.
  • Provide authorization control on tools and data that can be used.
  • A clean separation between AI application logic and ERP system.

Sample Architecture setup.

Step - by - step building an MCP server.

Let us consider the table SFLIGHT which holds flight connection data.

Create a CDS view and OData service that can expose SFLIGHT data as a REST API call.

Create and Activate the service

Sample entry through the created OData service for SFLIGHT data.

Create an MCP server to access OData service as an MCP tool.

Using FastMCP to create an MCP server that calls an OData service at the backend.

We need to next establish a connection between the on premise S/4HANA system and the MCP server on BTP.

We can accomplish this using the SAP Connectivity service and through cloud connector.

Cloud connector exposed back-end systems are now visible in the BTP cockpit for your account.

Deploy application on BTP.

MCP server is now running on BTP

Visualize the tools available and the MCP server through MCP Inspector.

Create a Basic ReACT agent and bind it with the MCP server.

Running the react agent with the query “Can you get plane type for carrier AA and connection 0017”

Flight information is correctly read and displayed.

entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to change field status of Purchase Requisition
entry.content:
Problem Background:

We received a customer request: when creating a purchase requisition, they want the Valuation Price field to be optional, but in the current system this field is mandatory.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. After searching in SAP for Me, we found a KBA 3322867 - Valuation Price field is mandatory in Create Purchase Requisitions app - SAP for Me which provides a solution to this problem. So we can try to use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PR_ FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to solve this problem.

2. We enter APP Custom Logic to create an implementation. The description of this BAdI is "Change of Field Control for Purchase Requisitions". In the documentation, we can get more information including supported fields. "PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE - Valuation Price" is included, that means our requirement can be fulfilled by this BAdI.

3. With this BAdI, we can set four status for supported fields of Purchase Requisition: Hidden, Read-only, Mandatory, Optional.

  • '-': To hide the field
  • '*': To make the field read-only
  • '+': To make the field mandatory
  • '.': To make the field optional

4. The sample code of this BAdI is quite readable and easy. Based on this problem, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

FIELD-SYMBOLS <fs> TYPE mmpur_s_pr_fldsel.

READ TABLE fieldselection_table ASSIGNING <fs> WITH KEY field = 'PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE'.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
    <fs>-fieldstatus = '.'.
ENDIF.

5. After testing, the BAdI works prefect. This BAdI not only supports GUI APP - Create Purchase Requisition - Advanced, but also supports Fiori APP - Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
You can find more information about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement-related issues at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

You can also read more blogs about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

If you have any suggestions or thoughts about this article, please feel free to share them in the comments section. I look forward to communicating with you. You are also welcome to follow my personal account, and I look forward to seeing you in the next blog post!

entry.title: Why SAP RPT‑1 Matters for Today’s and Future Generative AI in Predictive Business Insights?
entry.content:
Ever since the introduction of ChatGPT in November 2022, Generative AI has reshaped the AI industry. Companies like Amazon, Google, Microsoft, and of course SAP have accelerated innovation, recognizing the enormous value Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) bring to enterprise operations. 

General‑purpose LLMs excel at understanding language, reasoning over text, and identifying patterns in unstructured information. They are creative, adaptive, and capable of leveraging data from files, documents, and multimedia across diverse data systems.

The Motive

However, when it comes to actually predicting business outcomes, LLMs fall short. Why?
Because they are not designed for high‑precision, multi‑step reasoning over large, enterprise‑grade tabular datasets.

And this is where the majority of business data resides: structured tables, such as GL accounts, invoices, inventory, sales records, financial transactions, and countless others. Not in free‑form text.

Everyone wants to be able to predict business outcomes like:

  • What is the probability of converting a sale?
  • Which customers are likely to pay late?
  • Who is at risk of churn?
  • ...
Historically, answering these questions required traditional machine learning like classification models, linear regression, etc. (a.k.a Traditional AI or Narrow AI). The problem with this is that classical ML requires to train a model per task, which easily can lead to hundreds of separate models hard to maintain in the long run, making it very cumbersome, expensive and extremely difficult to scale.
 
 
The Solution: SAP RPT-1
 
To solve this, SAP introduced in TechEd 2025 the first foundation model specifically designed for structured enterprise data: Relational Pre‑Trained Transformer 1 (RPT‑1).  The model is trained natively on tabular business datasets and is engineered to understand rows, columns, joins and business semantics out of the box. As the name suggests, RPT‑1 is:
  • Relational: optimized for structured relational business data
  • Pre‑trained: powered by tens of thousands of GPU hours (no more endless classical ML training cycles)
  • Transformer‑based: performs logical, not linguistic, transformations (e.g., filtering, joining, aggregating, and multi‑step reasoning)

Instead of hundreds of ML models, you now can use one single foundation model for many predictive tasks.

One of the most disruptive features of RPT‑1 is its in‑context learning capability. Instead of training or fine‑tuning multiple modes, you simple provide historical rows of data and request predictions for new rows. Prediction cases like:

  • Customer churn prediction
  • Late delivery prediction
  • Late payment prediction
  • Sales conversion prediction
  • And many more

RPT‑1 Performance Benchmark

RPT-1 outperforms both LLM and classical ML for tabular data and high value agentic cases. Here are some stats so far:

  • 50x faster than LLMs
  • Up to 2x Prediction Quality vs Narrow AI/ML Models
  • Up to 3.5x Prediction Quality vs LLMs
  • 100,000x fewer GPU FLOPs
  • 50,000x Less Energy consumption vs LLMs*

*comparable tasks on a NVIDIA H100, as a benchmark. Sources (TechEd, Blog) .

Why are these stats so important? On top of the benefits you can already imagine like time and resource savings; according to Gartner 40% of agentic-AI projects are likely to be canceled by end of 2027, mainly because of high cost, complexity, or unclear business value (source). RPT‑1 directly addresses these challenges.

 

Sales Conversion Prediction Example Use Case

During SAP TechEd, a compelling demo showcased how RPT‑1 integrates with SAP’s Agentic AI.

Imagine a sales team wanting to prioritize leads based on their likelihood to convert. Instead of manually training an ML model, a data analyst can use Joule to generate SQL code leveraging RPT‑1’s PREDICT function.

Steps include:

  1. Join sales inquiries, historical performance, customer attributes, and other relevant data into a Data Product in SAP Business Data Cloud.
  2. Expose the Data Product to SAP HANA Cloud via zero‑copy.
  3. Use RPT‑1 to instantly generate a new prediction column "sales_conversion_probability"; without training or tuning.

The model derives patterns directly from the historical data and produces high‑quality prediction scores.

You can watch the full demo here (jump to minute 35:23).

 

Available RPT‑1 Versions

SAP RPT‑1 has been generally available since Q4 2025. You can choose from:

  • SAP RPT‑1 Small: optimized for speed and efficiency
  • SAP RPT‑1 Large: optimized for highest accuracy by using more capacity
  • SAP RPT‑1 OSS (Open Source): available on HuggingFace and Github for exploration and learning

Try it yourself!

Don’t have access to a BTP account yet? here is an entry point:

  • Sign up for a 30-day SAP Generative AI Hub trial
  • Follow this step-by-step guide to get started by @sherene_tan 

 

Conclusion

SAP RPT‑1 represents a major shift in how enterprises will deliver predictive insights in the GenAI era. While LLMs excel at language understanding, they are not built for structured, relational business data. RPT‑1 closes this gap and eliminates the complexity of traditional machine learning, drastically reducing cost and compute.

With SAP RPT-1's foundation model purpose‑built for enterprise-grade tabular data, the objective is to enable organizations to operationalize predictive insights faster, more efficiently, and more accurately than ever before.

entry.title: Exchange Rate Conversion in I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'm working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and using the I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 CDS view for project forecasting reporting. Currently, the cube displays amounts in USD, but I need to convert them to our company currency (KRW) for reporting purposes.

I have the following questions:

1. CDS View for Currency Conversion:

  • Is there a standard CDS view that extends I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 with currency conversion to company currency (KRW)?

  • If not, what is the recommended approach to implement currency conversion in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Should I create a custom CDS view using the CURRENCY_CONVERSION function?

2. Exchange Rate Type and Timing:

I understand that exchange rate type P (Planning Rate) is used for project planning. However, I need clarification on the following:

  • Plan values: Are they converted using the exchange rate P valid at the time of plan document creation (based on posting date or document date)?

  • Actual values: Are they converted using the exchange rate at the actual posting date of each transaction?

  • ETC (Estimate to Complete): Which exchange rate date is used - current forecast period or a specific date?

  • EAC (Estimate at Completion): Does it follow the same logic as Plan, or is there a different timing rule?

3. Documentation:

Is there any official SAP documentation or Note that describes the exchange rate timing rules for Plan/Actual/ETC/EAC in PS/EPPM module for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Background:

  • System: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Module: EPPM (PS)

  • CDS View: I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2

  • Source Currency: USD

  • Target Currency: KRW

  • Exchange Rate Type: P

Any guidance or reference to official documentation would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance!

Best regards,

entry.title: Management of Mold Manufacturing
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

Our factory carries out mold manufacturing operations. For certain stages of the molds produced, subcontracting services are obtained from external companies. During the mold manufacturing process, various raw materials are combined and processed, resulting in the final product, the mold.

When we attempt to manage this process as an ongoing investment, we have identified that we are unable to track the inventory of our materials that are located at the subcontractor’s site. On the other hand, when we try to manage the process using a subcontracting routing, this approach does not yield healthy results for us due to the mold manufacturing lead time exceeding one month and the WIP process being closed.

We do not prefer to create separate material master records for each component, as we believe that generating an excessive number of material codes would unnecessarily complicate the system. Once the mold manufacturing is completed and the mold is received into inventory, it will be managed as a fixed asset.

Within this framework, we would highly appreciate your valuable opinions and recommendations on how this process can be correctly and traceably designed in SAP.
In your opinion, what would be the healthiest way to manage this process?

Kind regards,

entry.title: Access SAP S/4HANA Transaction Codes in SAP BTP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
Hello Everybody,

 

Writing this blog to explain how we can access the SAP Transaction Codes of S/4HANA On Premise (SAP Rise) from SAP BTP Build Work Zone. SAP S/4HANA Rise system is a private cloud example, we can use public cloud also.

Here we are using SAP BTP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition. You can also use SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition also.

Prerequisites: Below are the prerequisites before we start:

-> Within the global account, you should subscribed to SAP Build Work Zone, standard edtion Service and Configured the Cloud Identity Service. The Work Zone will use Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to authenticate the Business Users.

-> In the Cloud Connector, configure the backend s/4hana system with https port for secure tunneled access and exchange the certifiate for Principal Propagation (The user of PP should be same in IAS and S4)

-> Destination should be there in the Sub account and choose the Principal Propagation as authentication.

 

Configuration:  There are 2 ways to configure the application, Page, spaces etc. in the build work zone:

1. Content Federation from S/4HANA system: In this we need to create the artifacts (Space, Pages, app etc.) in the S4 system and federate the content by making the content channel.

2. Local Artifcats in the Work Zone: Create Local Apps, Pages, spaces, groups etc. as required in the build work zone, standard edition.

 

We will be using the 2nd option as we are going to create local content in the work zone. Below are the configuration steps:

Step 1: Create App in the work zone

Access the Build Work Zone from the Sub account and got to Content Manager

Create a local app in the work zone, choose System (Destination) and form App UI Technology choose the SAP GUI for HTML

in this case, I have choosen the below transaction code, here we can put any transaction code as required

Step 2: Create page and assign app to page

Create a page and assign the appto page as below:

 

Step 3: Create Space and assign page to Space

 

Step 4: Create Role and assign app, space to role

 

Step 5:  Assign role to the site so it will be visible in site

Step 6: Assign role to user in Sub Account

Please note, Role created in the Work Zone will be shown as Role Collection in the Sub Account. So go to sub account and choose Role Collection and assign user to it.

 

Result: After Configuration all the above steps, when user will access the Work Zone then they can able to access the SAP S/4HANA transaction code as below:

 

I Hope this blog will help people to configure the SAP Transaction Code in Build Work Zone quickly without any issue.

 

Regards,

Rohit Gera

entry.title: Best Practice for Adjusting Project Progress Percentage in Review Customer Project
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'm working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition(fiori), and I need clarification on the standard process for adjusting project progress percentage when it doesn't match external tracking systems.

Current Situation:

  • External stakeholders track project progress separately, and their progress % often differs from SAP's calculated PoC

  • I need to increase or decrease progress percentage during the project lifecycle to align with external reporting

My Current Process:

  • During the project: I've been adjusting Plan values (increasing or decreasing planned costs) app to manipulate the progress percentage

  • At project end: I set ETC to 0 and run event-based revenue recognition to force 100% completion

  • I have NOT been setting forecast months regularly throughout the project

My Questions:

  1. Is adjusting Plan values the correct approach for mid-project progress reconciliation, or should I be using ETC adjustments instead?

  2. What is the SAP-recommended standard practice for ongoing progress alignment when external progress differs from system-calculated PoC?

  3. Should I be using forecast month settings systematically throughout the project lifecycle rather than only at project closure?

  4. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?

  5. Are there official SAP guidelines or best practice documents for PoC adjustments in the Review Customer Project app?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Thanks for taking up this difficult topic.

I see some large problems with the shift left approach so I fully agree that we will see a hybrid going forward.

The problems I see are

a) Back-end designers and developers don't understand what it data it takes to do analysis or even make AI on data

b) Back-end designers and developers are under pressure to deliver features and functionality not down-stream analytical useability

c) Not all can be standard and standards are not flexible.

ad a) The BW business content for ewm was a perfect example of back-end developers trying to deliver what they imagined was needed. The problem was that they did not understand the BW model leaving parts of the content pretty useless.

ad b) Most of us are measured on delivering results as fast as possible and that is not taking into account how much time is used down-stream by other teams.

ad c) In e.g. sales we we partner functions, some are standard like sold-to and ship-to but we have 3 custom partner functions that we can't run the business without. This will never come out of the box. Another example is classification data for materials. Using data products makes it worse as they are very inflexible of nature.

With kind regards

Kristian Appel

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - ( IA | CPI ) - The Commander's Blueprint: Rebuilding B2B EDI Governance with SAP
entry.content:
A long blog that could cover multiply topics. 

There is a number of decisions to take as a part of understanding your future EDI setup. 

Using the Standard TPM content is a good way to avoid the hey we just can just build it. It is a little as painful as building something in SAP PI where you where forced to use the framework. But here it makes a lot of sense to ensure you can build something that scales. 

Having a solid framework for governance around the TPM setup and roles is crucial. That include change history, transport and testing to understand what is going on. Here Figaf tool can help. 

There is a lot of strange rules inside your B2B Mappings because someone interpreted the business logic and someone else created the rules for it. Ideally we get out of this mess and get more clearly defined messages. But that would require a huge effort to find all the documents created. And MIG / MAG + a good sharepoint place to add all the documents too would make a huge difference.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_from_Madrid 

to be honest... I read your blog twice, but still asking myself: "Where is the beef?"

I still don't understand your intention or your goal of this Blog?!

I've been a BW consultant for 20 years now, and I can fully agree with your BW part: Extractors, and especially BI Content have been the "data products" of today, for over 25 years, without any specific term. And I think even today, that content contained more than the current Data Products in SAP Datasphere... not only because there is none in SD or MM LoB, but also because there have been features and functionalities already 20 years ago, for which we have to fight via the influence portal, to get them again.

One example... and I'm sure, this will be one of the last things, around 2029 to be delivered, if at all: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/365526  

And one last thought... what bothers me from the beginning of the introduction of the term "data product" ... for me, a product is something that is basically finished, like goods you buy in a shop: Pants, Jacket, Refrigerator, TV, a car etc. it is like you bought it and does not change, unless you customize it by yourself.

For e.g. a final Forecast, Plan or Budget version, the term "data product" applies... it does not change anymore (usually). But for master data or actuals data, it changes every hour, every day... it is a temporary product only. Especially if a process changes, the same data exists as "old and new" data product, if e.g. more document types are contained in one year than the other (just an example).

I know, I will not be able to change this "logic", but I think it is still worth thinking about it. 😉

BR, Martin

entry.title: Re: Completing a Project in CLOUD ALM

Hello Bala, 

Currently, archiving a project is the way to close/complete it. 
After archiving a project, it will be removed from the active list, and you can find it in the archived list.
If you expect to have a confirm/complete/close project option, you may post this requirement in the Influence website for implementation:https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/3501.
